annotation.TEXT: The M-445's are completely invincible, yet are attracted to these machines if you power them up. I honestly don't understand this enemy change. Yes, they can chase you through-out this section (which is the only one they appear in), but they're so slow that they'll probably never reach you (even with the Anko mini-bosses in the way).

Picopico-kun's room has now doubled in size, if mainly to accommodate for some of its new attack patterns. While it's certainly an interesting way to change this boss in theory, but for its execution here, it's a bit annoying. This is mostly because you have little to no warning when it comes to both these new attack patterns, and when two of them spawn in on opposite sides of the room.
Elec Man's fortress stage is pretty straight-froward for the most part. There's no real changes or variations to his gimmicks, aside from the level itself now largely being underwater.

Aside from this fight taking place in a vertical scrolling area, the Dragon hasn't changed much. He does have one new (albeit, very odd) attack, where both his feet will detach and fire up from the bottom of the screen on either side.

Also, another quick bit of advice: Kill Flash Man first. Bubble Man might be the bigger projectile spammer, but killing him first will cause Flash Man to flip out and start running back and forth, making him harder to avoid and even more annoying to hit. Bubble Man doesn't really get a mode like that if you beat Flash Man first, and he's generally easier to hit anyways.

Quick bit of advice: Don't bother fighting the Sniper Joes unless you absolutely have to. They're completely invincible when they have their shields up (even if you hit them from behind with the Rolling Cutter). There's no fancy tricks to get around them like in MM5 (or MM10). Just avoid them and move on.

Ice Man is up next, and once again, his gimmick revolves around freezing stage hazards (though instead of lava, you get to freeze those crushers from Metal Man's stage). Even though there's still a bit of wait time involved with all this, it's thankfully nowhere near as tedious as Heat Man's stage was.

Looks a bit familiar, right? Instead of the Guts Dozer, you now get to fight the two Robot Masters that were left out of the initial stages. Bubble Man and Flash Man are actually tougher than you might expect, if mostly due to how much of the screen their combined bullets tend to fill up. Flash Man will actively jump over your shots as well, and the Bubble Lead can actually block your Thunder Beam.

Unlike in this game's sequel, your character is actually predetermined for each fortress stage (mostly since each one is built around gimmicks that only specific RMs can get by). The first stage has you start off with Cut Man, which sadly plays out like a duller version of Wood Man's stage: You focus even less on stage gimmicks, and more-so on a bunch of annoying enemies.

Time to finally move on to the fortress levels. While this part of the game isn't quite as annoying as most of the main stages, it's still not much of a point in its favor. All of the stages are still a pain to get through, but these ones are at least generally shorter and less tedious by comparison (for the most part, anyways).

These "Laser Turrets" (which are obviously just repurposed background sprites from the original Wily 1) are actually kind of interesting. The only problem is that they're introduced in combination with those birds. Trying to stay low to avoid the laser and deal with the smaller birds at the same time (which can usually only be avoided by jumping) is far more trouble than necessary.
